snippet.textDisplay:
Option 1) Mexican woman writes a book catering to Mexican-Americans and it reaches practically no one and changes none of the minds it does reach because they already know the hardships.

Option 2) Whiter woman writes the same book catering to a whiter audience and it blows up and everyone talks about racial issues. Some minds are changed (how many is questionable but no doubt there are some).

It seems pretty clear to me. People are always trying to say who is qualified to write about what, but if we took that solid approach, we wouldn't have a lot of the great books we enjoy today. Can you imagine if we made it an immoral thing for anyone to write a book about a soldier without themselves having been a soldier? A good ninety percent or more of the great books of history having anything to do with warfare would be eliminated.

snippet.textDisplay:
Opinion time:
The book reminds me of the same way people reacted when 13 Reasons Why was causing a lot of issues. It’s basically a PSA. I realize that people often discredit viewpoints coming from people who haven’t personally experienced the things they are speaking on, but we live in a day where we positively recognize that people in a position in publicity often use that platform to speak out on things they believe in. So why are people so quick to turn on someone who is using a HUGE platform to tell the stories (even if it is a little sugar coated) of people who don’t have that opportunity? You’re right, it is a Trojan horse; the same way the rest of our current PSA’s are. If it makes you uncomfortable, it’s working. If it makes you uncomfortable, be the change you want to see so our fellow humans don’t have to have anymore experiences like this.

snippet.textDisplay: I think there was reason for annoyance, but not hate, in the first story about the gay couple in Applebee's. How would you feel about a straight couple making out in Applebee's? I've seen a photo of a gay couple kissing at a wedding displayed in an office environment, and was annoyed with it, but didn't understand why my annoyance could be valid until I realized I don't remember seeing any pictures of straight couples kissing in an office environment. Hate is likely also influenced with the association and lewd behavior gay pride has had (just look at the videos conservative media has of pride parades, and imagine how that makes those who want no public lewd displays feel, not saying all or even most pride events or parades are like that). I'd be annoyed with anyone, straight or gay, making out in an Applebee's within my sight. Like I told my sister's boyfriend, I'm fine with you staying over, as long as I don't hear or see anything.

snippet.textDisplay: I’ve read quite a few books now where I didn’t research the racial origin of the author- and I just read the story. The stories provided a window into a way of life I had little to no prior knowledge of, creating more empathy in myself I believe. I don’t think we need to tell stories from exclusively the lens of our own racial origin- that really limits the endless wonderland that is writing :/ I would have a hard time telling my grade 9 students, of all different backgrounds, who I am trying to encourage to love writing, to “stay in their lane.”

snippet.textDisplay: American dirt is modern fiction right? Not a biography? Cause if suddenly only latinx authors can write latinx based fiction/fantasy then would it be fair to criticize white authors for writing diversity into their books? Is suddenly the concept of listening to one another and sharing each other’s stories foreign? Historical fiction is a genre yet none of those authors are asked to live in those time periods before creating a romanticized adventure. I think publishers need to be making more diverse book deals and there needs to be a greater promotion of diverse biographies in order to gain a better perspective on the world. But there should be no shame in and author watching the world around them and imagining the story.

snippet.textDisplay:
Looking at just mortality rate to determine if this is serious or not is incorrect.

The Wuhan Virus has infected 10,000 people. 2000 of those people are in a severe medical episode, they're classified as critical. 250 people have died. The virus infects not just the old & young but those that are healthy.

The 18 year medical difference between the timing of SARS and the Wuhan virus is why the death toll is so low, if this virus happened when SARS did, it would be much more severe.

The reason China is taking drastic steps is because the 10,000 people infected, those are only the "confirmed" cases. That means 2-4 tests need to be completed before it can be called definitive. Wuhan City has only 6 hospitals with a carrying capacity totalling about 5,000-7,000 people, the hospitals were already full before the virus hit. The amount of people waiting to be tested & the backlog of testing all samples. The real amount of people infected is peaking 200,000 or more as of today. Every person infects 3 people and you dont need to have symptoms to pass it along.

China has taken heroic efforts to contain this. It's actually a massive feat when you think about the density and scale of Wuhan and the surrounding cities.

Imagine New York shutting down for two weeks, Time Square being completed deserted. Subway being shut off and only a select amount of Taxis on the road.

Will this wipe out humanity? Naw. It's going to kill a lot of people though, especially if it spreads to places like India and countries that can't do what China has so far done.
